Award.AwardTitle: Teacher Professional Development for Technology-Enhanced Inquiry to Foster Students' 21st Century Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Exploratory Design and Development Teaching project is to develop and evaluate a module for use in a 7th grade classroom that promotes student development of 21st Century skills with a particular focus on student development of scientific reasoning. The technology-enhanced curriculum will be designed to engage learners in deep and meaningful investigations to promote student learning of content in parallel with 21st century skills. The module will be designed using principles of inquiry-based learning as well as the principles of universal design for learning (UDL). The motivation behind this project is that it will directly contribute to the limited research on the interventions that impact teachers' capacity to provide high quality 21st century STEM education to all students, with a specific focus on underrepresented minorities and those with disabilities. The classroom setting for which the curriculum will be delivered is within an urban district which includes a large number of minority students and over 20% students with specific learning disabilities. The project will catalyze students' deep understanding of content knowledge while developing 21st century skills in parallel; hence better preparing students for sustainable learning experiences into high school and beyond.

A study will be conducted to determine the effectiveness of the learning modules on classroom practices as well as student learning. A mixed methods design involving multiple measures will provide insights into changes in teachers' content knowledge, teaching practices that include a focus on 21st century learning, and fidelity of use of the TI21 framework for implementation of the learning activities. Pre- and post-testing of students using a scientific reasoning assessment and surveys on attitudes towards STEM, along with validated and widely used concept inventories, will provide further measures. As part of this exploratory project, the design and validity of instruments for use with the targeted population, which includes students with specific learning disabilities, will be further tested. This will include administering some of the assessments through web-based apps to meet the needs of these students. The learning modules, with embedded assessments and web-based apps, will provide an innovative approach in which transferable 21st century skills can be developed and measured. Outcomes of this project will be disseminated throughout the urban school system and therefore have the ability to impact thousands of other students (mostly minorities and many with disabilities) and their science, math, and technology teachers. Project outcomes will also inform the development of future science and/or modules for use in similar urban classroom settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project directly contributes to the limited research on the interventions that impact middle school teachers’ capacity to provide high quality 21st century STEM education to all students, with a specific focus on those with learning disabilities. It provides an innovative approach to address the need for curriculum and assessments that help students acquire advanced problem-solving abilities including those related to scientific thinking; e.g. ability to analyze a problem, seek relevant data, test new and familiar concepts, and process information. Products include lessons which support two areas of scientific reasoning, control of variables and proportional reasoning, along with a related 15-item multiple choice assessment for middle school use. 

Both the windmill engineering design project, which targets control variable reasoning, and the set of lessons around problem solving with ratios and proportions, were developed using a scientific reasoning curricular framework developed under another project (see figure). They were also developed based on principles of universal design for learning (UDL). Strategies were used to help students build information in long-term memory, such as checkpoints that engage the teacher in Socratic dialogue with students. Visuals, such as drawings or tables, were used to support working memory, and also enabled teachers to use gesturing during discussions to draw attention to key pieces of information, thereby making information easier to process, remember, and combine. The lessons and assessment were implemented across 30 classrooms during the project period. Feedback from students, teachers, and assessment results informed all revisions.

Multiple project findings contribute to the research literature. In particular, student deficiencies in student thinking were realized during lesson implementation. This included finding that middle school students in general lack procedural methodology and understanding of the cyclic process involved in scientific inquiry. In the windmill lesson, for example, students were able to conduct a single experiment with control variables, but 75% of the groups under study demonstrated difficulty transferring what was learned from the initial experiment to subsequent experiments, a process important to scientific inquiry and engineering design. The lesson went through multiple revisions and included redesigning the paper format into Google Slides, which were launched through Google Classroom. Each slide involved less material and additional questions were included to engage students in desired thinking. The revised lesson was highly effective and engaged nearly all groups of students in appropriate scientific inquiry (Koenig et al., 2017). In addition, through classroom observations, teacher interviews, and written reflections, the new format was also found to work well with all students, regardless of learning disability. The Google Slides, and lessons learned, now serve as a vetted lesson template, disseminated through the NSTA Science Scope website. It can be adapted by others for additional science and engineering design topics, thereby helping support the transition from content-oriented teaching to ability fostering across the STEM disciplines.

In addition, the proportional reasoning activities were found to be effective in moving students away from “additive” reasoning towards recognizing and applying proportional relationships in solving certain problem types. That is, student progress was observed on post-test questions involving real-life, common tasks, but did not transfer to situations involving lab-based tasks. Although this adds to the current research literature, additional lessons should be developed to address areas for which students still struggle.

Another important outcome involves the development of a reasoning assessment format that, based on preliminary pilot data, was found to be more accessible to students with learning disabilities. This format replaces a paper and pencil version of the test, and involves read-aloud accommodation (video) with teacher use of gestures. This alternative assessment was designed to reduce testing barriers related to learning disabilities, such as reading and working memory-related issues. This tentative finding adds to the knowledge base on pedagogical methods and assessments that support students with LD in STEM education.

And finally, this project involved several cohorts of teachers implementing the curriculum and assessments. Essential elements of professional developed were identified, which may provide guidance to others working in similar circumstances. This includes the need to offer professional development which: (1) allows teachers to work through the materials themselves, playing the role of student, to help uncover their own incorrect ideas while helping them recognize “problem” areas in the lesson; (2) educates teachers on features of the lessons which promote skill development so they are not omitted or hurried through during implementation; (3) educates teachers on the effective use of Socratic dialogue (checkpoints); and (4) helps teachers set up the needed technology, such as Google Slides on Google Classroom.

Koenig, K., Zydney, J., Behr, D., & Bao, L. (2017).  Enhancing a Scientific Inquiry Lesson through Computer Supported Collaborative Learning. Science Scope, 82-89.
